Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Okay let me tackle this problem step by step First I need to understand the given temporal profile and identify the anomalies The user provided a dictionary with average times and standard deviations between activities The task is to spot any unusual averages or standard deviations

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Starting with the R to P Receive to Approve entry The average is 90000 seconds which is 25 hours The STDEV is 3600 seconds 1 hour Hmm the STDEV being so low compared to the mean suggests very little variation which might mean that approvals are happening almost exactly on a fixed schedule like an automated process or strict deadlines enforced Thats suspicious because real processes usually have more variability unless somethings forcing the timing

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Next the P to N Approve to Notify has an average of 604800 seconds 7 days with a 2 day STDEV Thats a long delay but the STDEV is large meaning sometimes its much longer or shorter Maybe approvals are backlogged so sometimes notifications get delayed a lot but sometimes theyre quick if handled manually when they get to the top of the queue Or maybe theres a separate process for approvals and notifications thats inconsistent

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: A to C Assign to Close averages 2 hours with 1 hour STDEV Thats a short time Since the process steps include Evaluate and Approve after Assign closing so quickly might mean that some claims are being closed prematurely skipping steps Maybe some claims are rejected early so they go straight from Assign to Close bypassing Evaluate and Approve Or perhaps theres an error in logging the events missing some steps

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: E to N Evaluate to Notify has a 5 minute average with a 1 minute STDEV Thats really quick Maybe the evaluation and notification are automated and linked tightly but if theres supposed to be an approval step in between thats missing Or maybe the Evaluate step is just a formality and notifications go out immediately after evaluation which might skip the approval step indicating a process flaw

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Now generating hypotheses for each anomaly Lets see For R to Ps low STDEV Maybe theres an automated system that triggers approval exactly 25 hours after receiving the claim so the STDEV is low Or maybe the system is configured to approve claims at a specific time each day leading to consistent delays Alternatively some claims are being fast tracked incorrectly forcing them into a narrow timeframe

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: For P to Ns long delay Maybe after approval theres a manual step thats backlogged or notifications are delayed due to waiting for another department The high STDEV could mean that sometimes its handled quickly if urgent but usually takes weeks

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: A to Cs short time Perhaps claims are being assigned and then closed immediately if theyre invalid so they dont go through evaluation Or maybe the system allows closing without proper steps leading to errors in the process

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: E to Ns quick time The evaluation might automatically trigger a notification without needing approval which could mean the approval step is being bypassed Or maybe the approval is done as part of evaluation but the temporal model expects them to be separate steps

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Now for the SQL queries The user wants to verify these anomalies Lets think about each case For R to P Find claims where the time between R and P is close to the average 25h with low variance The query would calculate the time between these two events and check if their distribution matches the low STDEV Maybe group by claim and see if most are within a narrow range

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For P to Ns long delay Find claims where the time between P and N is over 7 days and others where its much shorter Also check if theres a correlation with adjuster or region

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For A to C Find claims where the time from Assign to Close is under 2 hours and check if they have missing steps like Evaluate or Approve Maybe a query that checks if between Assign and Close there are no Evaluate or Approve events

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For E to Ns quick time Look for claims where Evaluate to Notify is under 5 minutes Check if those claims have an approval step in between or if they skipped it Also see if the same adjusters or regions have this pattern

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Also maybe look for claims that have a direct jump from Evaluate to Notify without the necessary steps in between For example after Evaluate the next should be Approve then Notify but if its jumping to Notify thats an issue

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Let me structure the queries properly Need to use the claim events table joining events by claim id ordering by timestamp For each pair of activities calculate the time difference

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For the first anomaly R to P SELECT claim id EXTRACT EPOCH FROM approve time receive time AS duration seconds FROM SELECT claim id MAX CASE WHEN activity R THEN timestamp END AS receive time MAX CASE WHEN activity P THEN timestamp END AS approve time FROM claim events GROUP BY claim id HAVING COUNT DISTINCT activity 2 AND MAX CASE WHEN activity R THEN 1 ELSE 0 END 1 AND MAX CASE WHEN activity P THEN 1 ELSE 0 END 1 AS sub WHERE approve time receive time Then compute the average and STDEV of duration seconds to see if it matches the given profile But the user wants to find claims that deviate Alternatively to check if most are close to 90000 seconds with low variance Another query could be to see the standard deviation of those durations But maybe the user just wants to flag claims where the duration is within a narrow range to confirm the low STDEV

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For the P to N anomaly 7 days with high stdev Find claims where the time between P and N is over 7 days plus 2 STDEVs or under Wait the average is 7 days so maybe check for instances where the duration is way above or below SELECT claim id notify time approve time AS duration FROM SELECT claim id MAX CASE WHEN activity P THEN timestamp END AS approve time MAX CASE WHEN activity N THEN timestamp END AS notify time FROM claim events GROUP BY claim id HAVING COUNT DISTINCT activity 2 AND MAX CASE WHEN activity P THEN 1 ELSE 0 END 1 AND MAX CASE WHEN activity N THEN 1 ELSE 0 END 1 sub WHERE notify time approve time AND EXTRACT EPOCH FROM notify time approve time 604800 2 172800 OR but maybe just list the durations and see the extremes Also to see if certain adjusters are involved in these outliers

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For A to C Assign to Close quickly Check claims where the time between Assign and Close is under 2 hours and see if they have Evaluate or Approve events in between A query that checks if between A and C there are any E or P events If not thats an issue SELECT c claim id a assign time c close time close time assign time AS duration FROM claim events WHERE activity A OR activity C GROUP BY claim id HAVING MAX CASE WHEN activity A THEN timestamp END MAX CASE WHEN activity C THEN timestamp END AND EXTRACT EPOCH FROM MAX CASE WHEN activity C THEN timestamp END MAX CASE WHEN activity A THEN timestamp END 7200 2 hours AND NOT EXISTS SELECT 1 FROM claim events ce WHERE ce claim id c claim id AND ce activity IN E P AND ce timestamp BETWEEN assign time AND close time Not sure about the exact syntax but the idea is to find claim ids where between Assign and Close there are no Evaluate or Approve steps indicating premature closure

Name: Validation - PE
Text: For E to N 5 minutes SELECT FROM claim events ce WHERE activity IN E N GROUP BY claim id HAVING EXTRACT EPOCH FROM MAX CASE WHEN activity N THEN timestamp END MIN CASE WHEN activity E THEN timestamp END 300 5 minutes AND NOT EXISTS SELECT 1 FROM claim events WHERE claim id ce claim id AND activity P AND timestamp BETWEEN evaluation time and notify time Wait need to check if the approval step P is missing between E and N

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Putting it all together the queries should look for these time discrepancies and missing steps Also correlating with adjuster or region by joining with the adjusters table where applicable I need to make sure each query addresses an anomaly and can be written in SQL Let me structure each part clearly
